text: No worries! So I studied Media Arts at Plymouth University which was a very art focused course. There was a lot of freedom in choosing what form of media to use in assignments with loads of tutorials and workshops for specific software or techniques such as chemical photography. It was a great course though I didn't really learn anything about animation and VFX as an industry, more about it as an art form. I was really interested in After Effects and how I could use it to create VFX for my projects, so I spent a lot of time learning via Youtube/Video Copilot tutorials and talking to the tutors and technicians from my faculty. So my degree wasn't vital to me getting a job but it did give me an environment in which I could develop my skills and understanding of animation and put them into practice.

I do think there could have been more of a career focused aspect to my course but I also got a strong sense that I got what I wanted from it, which was to figure out what kind of work I wanted to do in the future and build up my skills towards that.
Since working I feel like a lot of skills have been picked up through whichever position I was in at the time, although there are some basic skills which definitely helped me get my foot in the door.

When I started applying, I looked at lots of different branches of animation/VFX such as compositing, production and motion graphics. I was mainly applying for runner or assistant positions and I eventually found a vacancy at Jellyfish as a runner with the prospect of helping in Editorial. There's a scheme called Trainee Finder run by Creative Skillset, which meant that Jellyfish could take me on as a trainee and I could still get paid which was vital for me as I had to support myself and couldn't take unpaid positions (of which there are many sadly).

Here's a link to Trainee Finder in case you haven't heard of it, looks like it's rebranded to Screen Skills but still the same thing: <https://www.screenskills.com/education-training/trainee-finder/>
Hope that helps, feel free to ask me to elaborate on anything or let me know if I didn't quite answer the question haha.
